content.question: For an experiment, <math alttext="50.0 grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was added to a coffee-cup calorimeter, as shown in the diagram above. The initial temperature of the <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was <math alttext="22.0 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>22.0</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and it absorbed <math alttext="300 decimal point joules" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>300.</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>J</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of heat from an object that was carefully placed inside the calorimeter. Assuming no heat is transferred to the surroundings, which of the following was the approximate temperature of the <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> after thermal equilibrium was reached? Assume that the specific heat capacity of <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="4.2 joules per gram per Kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>J/(g</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>K)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 2.D: Make observations or collect data from representations of laboratory setups or results, while attending to precision where appropriate.
